For what it's worth, here's my $0.02....

Neat works on two quite different=
 time-scales. You have the
'optimising weights' timescale which is fast, an=
d the 'optimising
topology' timescale which is slow. Just like any GA, a na=
ieve NEAT
would suffer from premature convergence. Because of the differing=

timescales, in the absence of any diversity maintenance, the GA would
conv=
erge on a vastly sub-optimal topology. To combat this, some kind
of diversi=
ty maintenance mechanism needs to be employed. Ken's
original neat uses the=
 fitness sharing method. There's no reason why
another decent diversity mai=
ntenance mechanism could not be employed.
